Welcome to Rest API’s documentation!¶

REST API main¶

main.healthchecker(db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The healthchecker function is a function that returns the message &quot;Welcome to FastAPI!&quot; if the database connection is successful. If there’s an error connecting to the database, it will return a 500 status code with an error message.

Parameters:

db – Session: Get the database connection from the dependency

Returns:

A dict with a message

Doc-author:

Trelent

async main.startup()¶

The startup function is called when the server starts up. It’s a good place to initialize things that are needed by your app, such as database connections.

Returns:

A fastapilimiter instance

Doc-author:

Trelent

REST API repository AuthUsers¶

async src.repository.authusers.confirmed_email(email: str, db: Session) → None¶

The confirmed_email function takes an email and a database session as arguments. It then gets the user from the database using their email address, sets their confirmed field to True, and commits that change to the database.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Get the email of the user

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

None

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.authusers.create_authuser(body: AuthUserModel, db: Session) → AuthUser¶

The create_authuser function creates a new user in the database. It takes an AuthUserModel object and a Session object as arguments, and returns an AuthUser object. The function first tries to get the Gravatar image for the email address provided in the body of the request, but if it fails it will just set avatar to None. It then uses **body.dict() to unpack the dictionary returned by body’s dict method into keyword arguments that are passed into creating a new instance of AuthUser (which is what we want). The function then adds this new user instance to our database session, commits

Parameters:

  • body – AuthUserModel: Pass the data from the request body to the function

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A new authuser object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.authusers.get_authuser_by_email(email: str, db: Session) → AuthUser¶

The get_authuser_by_email function takes in an email and a database session, and returns the AuthUser object associated with that email. If no such user exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Filter the database for a user with that email

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

An authuser object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.authusers.update_avatar(email, url: str, db: Session) → AuthUser¶

The update_avatar function takes an email and a url as arguments. It then uses the get_authuser_by_email function to retrieve the user from the database. The avatar property of that user is set to be equal to the url argument, and then the db session is committed.

Parameters:

  • email – Find the user in the database

  • url – str: Specify the type of data that is going to be passed into the function

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The updated user object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.authusers.update_token(user: AuthUser, token: str | None, db: Session) → None¶

The update_token function updates the refresh token for a user.

Parameters:

  • user – AuthUser: Identify the user in the database

  • token – str | None: Specify the type of token

  • db – Session: Commit the changes to the database

Returns:

None

Doc-author:

Trelent

REST API repository Users¶

async src.repository.users.create_user(body: UserModel, db: Session, user: AuthUser) → User¶

The create_user function creates a new user in the database.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Get the data from the request body

  • db – Session: Connect to the database

  • user – AuthUser: Get the user id from the authuser object

Returns:

The user object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.users.get_birthday_per_week(days: int, db: Session, user: AuthUser) → User¶
The get_birthday_per_week function returns a list of users whose birthday is within the next 7 days.
Args:

days (int): The number of days to look ahead for birthdays. db (Session): A database session object that can be used to query the database.

Parameters:

  • days – int: Specify the number of days in which we want to get the birthdays

  • db – Session: Access the database

  • user – AuthUser: Get the user id of the current logged in user

Returns:

A list of users whose birthdays are in the next 7 days

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.users.get_user(user_id: int, db: Session, user: AuthUser) → User¶

The get_user function takes in a user_id and returns the User object with that id. It also checks to make sure that the user is authorized to access this information.

Parameters:

  • user_id – int: Specify the user id of the user we want to get

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

  • user – AuthUser: Check if the user is logged in

Returns:

A user object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.users.get_users(skip: int, limit: int, db: Session, user: AuthUser) → List[User]¶

The get_users function returns a list of users.

Parameters:

  • skip – int: Skip a certain number of users in the database

  • limit – int: Limit the number of users returned

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

  • user – AuthUser: Get the user’s id from the database

Returns:

A list of users

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.users.get_users_by_some_info(some_info: str, db: Session, user: AuthUser) → List[User]¶
The get_users_by_some_info function takes a string and returns a list of users that have the string in their first name, second name or email.
Args:

some_info (str): The string to search for. db (Session): A database session object. user (AuthUser): An authenticated user object.

Parameters:

  • some_info – str: Pass the information that we want to search for

  • db – Session: Create a connection to the database

  • user – AuthUser: Get the user id from the database

Returns:

A list of users with the specified information

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.users.remove_user(user_id: int, db: Session, user: AuthUser) → User | None¶
The remove_user function removes a user from the database.
Args:

user_id (int): The id of the user to be removed. db (Session): A session object for interacting with the database.

Parameters:

  • user_id – int: Specify the user id of the user to be deleted

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

  • user – AuthUser: Check if the user is authorized to delete a user

Returns:

The user that was deleted or none if the user didn’t exist

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.repository.users.update_user(user_id: int, body: UserModel, db: Session, user: AuthUser) → User | None¶
The update_user function updates a user in the database.
Args:

user_id (int): The id of the user to update. body (UserModel): The updated User object to store in the database.

Parameters:

  • user_id – int: Get the user with that id

  • body – UserModel: Pass the user model to the function

  • db – Session: Access the database

  • user – AuthUser: Get the user id from the token

Returns:

The updated user

Doc-author:

Trelent

REST API routes Auth¶

async src.routes.auth.confirmed_email(token: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The confirmed_email function is used to confirm a user’s email address.

It takes in the token that was sent to the user’s email and uses it to get their email address. Then, it gets the authuser object from that email and checks if they are already confirmed or not. If they are already confirmed, then we return a message saying so; otherwise, we update their account with confirmation.

Parameters:

  • token – str: Get the token from the url

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message to the user if their email is already confirmed

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.auth.login(body: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(NoneType), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The login function is used to authenticate a user. It takes the username and password from the request body, and returns an access token and refresh token if successful.

Parameters:

  • body – OAuth2PasswordRequestForm: Get the username and password from the request body

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

A dict with the access token, refresh token and token type

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.auth.refresh_token(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The refresh_token function is used to refresh the access token.

The function takes in a refresh token and returns an access_token, a new refresh_token, and the type of token. If there is no valid user associated with the given email address or if there is no valid user associated with that email address then it will return an HTTP 401 Unauthorized error.

Parameters:

  • credentials – HTTPAuthorizationCredentials: Get the token from the request

  • db – Session: Access the database

Returns:

A dictionary with the access_token, refresh_token and token type

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.auth.request_email(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The request_email function is used to send an email to the user with a link that they can click on to confirm their email address. The function takes in a RequestEmail object, which contains the user’s email address. It then checks if there is already an AuthUserModel object associated with that email address, and if so it sends them an email containing a link for them to click on.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Pass the email address to the function

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base url of the application

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A message to the user

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.auth.signup(body: AuthUserModel, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The signup function creates a new user in the database. It takes an AuthUserModel object as input, which contains the username and email of the new user. The function then checks if there is already a user with that email address in the database, and if so raises an exception. If not, it hashes the password using auth_service’s get_password_hash() function (which uses Argon2), sets body’s password to this hash value, and calls repository_users’ create_authuser() function to add it to db.

Parameters:

  • body – AuthUserModel: Get the data from the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base url of the application

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A dictionary with two keys: user and detail

Doc-author:

Trelent

REST API routes Avatar¶

async src.routes.avatar.read_authusers_me(current_user: AuthUser = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_authusers_me function returns the current user’s information.

Parameters:

current_user – AuthUser: Get the current user

Returns:

The current user

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.avatar.update_avatar_authuser(file: UploadFile = File(PydanticUndefined), current_user: AuthUser = Depends(get_current_user), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶
The update_avatar_authuser function takes in a file, current_user and db.

It then uploads the file to cloudinary using the public id of RestApi13/{current_user.username}{current_user.id} The function then returns a user with an updated avatar.

Parameters:

  • file – UploadFile: Upload the file to cloudinary

  • current_user – AuthUser: Get the current user

  • db – Session: Get the database session

Returns:

A user object

Doc-author:

Trelent

REST API routes Users¶

async src.routes.users.create_user(body: UserModel, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: AuthUser = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The create_user function creates a new user in the database.

It takes a UserModel object as input, and returns an HTTP response with the newly created user’s information.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Specify the type of data that will be passed to the function

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the repository

  • current_user – AuthUser: Get the current user from the database

Returns:

A usermodel object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.users.find_birthday_per_week(days: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: AuthUser = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The find_birthday_per_week function returns a list of users that have their birthday in the next 7 days.

The function takes an integer as input, which is the number of days to look ahead for birthdays. It then queries the database and returns a list of users with their birthday in that time frame.

Parameters:

  • days – int: Specify the amount of days that we want to search for birthdays

  • db – Session: Inject the database session into the function

  • current_user – AuthUser: Get the current user

Returns:

A list of users with a birthday in the next 7 days

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.users.find_users_by_some_info(some_info: str, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: AuthUser = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The find_users_by_some_info function is used to find users by some info.
Args:

some_info (str): The user’s name, email or phone number.

Parameters:

  • some_info – str: Pass the search string to the function

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • current_user – AuthUser: Get the current user

Returns:

A list of users

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.users.read_user(user_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: AuthUser = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_user function is a GET endpoint that returns the user with the given ID. If no such user exists, it raises an HTTP 404 error.

Parameters:

  • user_id – int: Specify the type of the parameter

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the repository layer

  • current_user – AuthUser: Get the current user

Returns:

A user

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.users.read_users(skip: int = 0, limit: int = 100, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: AuthUser = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The read_users function returns a list of users.

Parameters:

  • skip – int: Specify how many records to skip

  • limit – int: Limit the number of users returned

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the repository

  • current_user – AuthUser: Get the current user

Returns:

A list of users

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.users.remove_user(user_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: AuthUser = Depends(get_current_user))¶

The remove_user function removes a user from the database.

Parameters:

  • user_id – int: Specify the user id of the user to be deleted

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

  • current_user – AuthUser: Get the user id of the logged in user

Returns:

The removed user

Doc-author:

Trelent

async src.routes.users.update_user(body: UserModel, user_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db), current_user: AuthUser = Depends(get_current_user))¶
The update_user function updates a user in the database.

It takes an id, and a body containing the fields to update. The function returns the updated user.

Parameters:

  • body – UserModel: Specify the data that will be passed to the function

  • user_id – int: Get the user id from the url

  • db – Session: Get the database session

  • current_user – AuthUser: Get the current user

Returns:

A usermodel object

Doc-author:

Trelent

REST API service Auth¶

class src.services.auth.Auth¶

Bases: object

ALGORITHM = 'HS256'¶
SECRET_KEY = 'secret_key'¶
async create_access_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶

The create_access_token function creates a new access token. The function takes in the data to be encoded, and an optional expires_delta parameter. If no expires_delta is provided, the default value of 15 minutes will be used. The function then encodes the data using JWT with our SECRET_KEY and ALGORITHM.

Parameters:

  • self – Access the class attributes

  • data – dict: Pass the data that will be encoded into the token

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the access token

Returns:

A jwt token which is encoded with the data that we passed in as well as a few other values

Doc-author:

Trelent

create_email_token(data: dict)¶

The create_email_token function creates a token that is used to verify the user’s email address. The token contains the following information: - iat (issued at): The time when the token was created. - exp (expiration): The time when this token will expire and no longer be valid. This is set to 7 days from creation date by default, but can be changed in settings.py if desired.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that will be encoded into a token

Returns:

A token that is encoded with the user’s email and a secret key

Doc-author:

Trelent

async create_refresh_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶

The create_refresh_token function creates a refresh token for the user. The function takes in two arguments: data and expires_delta. Data is a dictionary containing the user’s id, username, email address, and password hash. Expires_delta is an optional argument that sets how long before the refresh token expires.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that will be encoded into the token

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the refresh token

Returns:

A refresh token

Doc-author:

Trelent

async decode_refresh_token(refresh_token: str)¶

The decode_refresh_token function is used to decode the refresh token. The function takes in a refresh_token as an argument and returns the email of the user if successful. If there is an error, it raises a HTTPException with status code 401 (UNAUTHORIZED) and detail message.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • refresh_token – str: Pass the refresh token to the function

Returns:

The email of the user that is associated with a valid refresh token

Doc-author:

Trelent

async get_current_user(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), db: Session = Depends(get_db))¶

The get_current_user function is a dependency that will be used in the protected endpoints. It takes a token as an argument and returns the user if it’s valid, or raises an exception otherwise.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of a class

  • token – str: Get the token from the request header

  • db – Session: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The user object

Doc-author:

Trelent

async get_email_from_token(token: str)¶

The get_email_from_token function takes a token as an argument and returns the email address associated with that token. The function first tries to decode the JWT using the SECRET_KEY and ALGORITHM defined in settings.py, then it extracts the sub (subject) from the payload of that decoded JWT, which is an email address. If there is no sub or if there are any other errors, then we raise a 422 Unprocessable Entity error.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • token – str: Pass in the token that was sent to the user’s email

Returns:

The email address that was used to create the token

Doc-author:

Trelent

get_password_hash(password: str)¶

The get_password_hash function takes a password and returns the hashed version of it. The hashing algorithm is defined in the settings file, which is imported at the top of this file.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • password – str: Specify the password to be hashed

Returns:

A hashed password

Doc-author:

Trelent

oauth2_scheme = <fastapi.security.oauth2.OAuth2PasswordBearer object>¶
pwd_context = <CryptContext>¶
r = Redis<ConnectionPool<Connection<host=localhost,port=6379,db=0>>>¶
verify_password(plain_password, hashed_password)¶

The verify_password function takes a plain-text password and hashed password as arguments. It then uses the CryptContext object to verify that the plain-text password matches the hashed one.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • plain_password – Store the password that is entered by the user

  • hashed_password – Check the password against the hashed version of it

Returns:

A boolean

Doc-author:

Trelent

REST API service Email¶

async src.services.email.send_email(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶

The send_email function sends an email to the user with a link to confirm their email address. The function takes in three parameters: -email: the user’s email address, which is used as a recipient for the message. -username: this is used in conjunction with host and token_verification to create a link that will be sent via email. This username parameter will be passed into auth_service’s create_email_token function, which returns a token that can then be verified by auth service’s verify_email function (see below). The username parameter is also included

Parameters:

  • email – EmailStr: Specify the email address of the recipient

  • username – str: Pass the username to the email template

  • host – str: Pass the hostname of the server to the template

Returns:

A coroutine, which is a special kind of object that can be used in an async context

Doc-author:

Trelent
